number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												This is a game, that, unlike a lot of greenlight games, doesn't deserve punishment for low effort.  Why, then, is Brink a bad product?  Because it's the perfect product to show off everything that's BAD about the new era of online gaming.   A huge amount of effort went into look, feel, quality, construction.   But they did just enough to achieve that, and ignored all gameplay, but they hit you hard and fast with demands for DLC purchases.   It could have been a contender.  But it's everything that's bad about the microtransaction era and nothing that's good about it.   We have a lot to learn from this failure.Technical:  No support for 4K earns an immediate thumbs down when your strategy is to release a high graphics cutting edge game.   It's smooth and fluid enough, but optimisation could be better.  Graphics:  They hired artists and put in a huge amount of effort refining the look and feel of the game, as well as hiring great voice actors, so you would think this is thumbs up territory.   This is why we have so much to learn from this game.Gameplay: Now here's where it gets controversial.   It's a mediocre arena shooter (like there aren't hundreds of these) with a fairly well done art style and even a plotty single player campaign.   But the single player is just the mediocre arena shooter with mediocre bots.   But balanced around PvP, badly.   No effort was put into gameplay balance.  No effort was put into refining this after the massive amount of effort put into polishing the game.  There's actually a single player storyline that might be quite interesting if it wasn't for the horrendous miscarriage that is the gameplay.All the effort in this game went into polish and DLC options, and none of it into the heart and soul of gameplay.  They give you no doubts when it comes to making sure you know they want your money.  But for what?  There's far better free arena FPS games.  Final note:  At this stage it's 4 years after launch, and the online servers are abandoned.  Even if you wanted to pay money to have a worse experience than the free arena shooters, you can't because there's not enough players.   They still want $10 for the full package though.   Go buy $10 worth of donuts and play TF2, you'll have a much better time.

content:
24, 2012
												Pretty balanced weaponry/gadgets and easy to use SMART system which is used for hopping walls, sliding, etc and requires teamwork with the use of 4 classes similar to Team Fortress 2(Soldier, Medic, Engineer, Operative) to win. The story is basic  with 2 factions opposing each other though neither are shown to be "evil" and can be played with 7 other players. Its adversarial modes and customization are where Brink shines with players able to change the appearance of his/her character(s), customize his/her weapons with multiple attachments which both are unlocked through completion of obstacle courses, and level up to unlock many abilities in each class catagory. Overall Brink is a decent game and is fun to play with/against others.

content:
, 2011
												GODSPEED's Review:Do Not judge the game before you play the game for atleast two days. The game is very different is what i had to say from it's first look.Do Not believe the reviews from IGN, they rushed in to put up a review.Game is not fun for long to be played as Solo, as the AI system is good but can be better. (Patch on it's way)Game is really fun to be played as a team, even if its against bots. Remember to always pick up missions on the go, as they win you games and are very rewarding.Completing the challenges is the best way to unlock most of the useful items/weapons.There is no in game currency as of yet other then trading ur leveling coins for abilites of your choice, which can be reset for a loss of a level.There are two different ways to grow in this game, leveling up and ranking up. Both are rewarding in their own way.It's true that you can have upto 42 trillion characters in this game but max of 10 at a time. The game should have been more polished to add on to the amazing look and promise of the different characters. It is a good part and a concept but not yet a game.It was really hard for me to recommend or not recommend this game but i want to recommend this to be played but not to spend out your dollars (so please buy it on sale... but not to late so you can enjoy the online experience) so you can see how much this game has in originality in character customization and shooting while sliding our jumping up a barrier. Tons of new stuff but not utlilized to  make the best of this amazing experience. I only wish they had a better way to ultilize the new concepts they developed because the wholed idea is unique and adds a different skill to a shoot out.NOT YET COMPLETE-GODSPEED

The art style, mechanics and customization, along with my fond PS3 memories of full 8v8 player teams back in the glory days combine to make this one of my favorite games of all time. If I had to pick ONE game to keep installed on my PC for the rest of my life, it would be Brink hands down. If not to play it, then at least for nostalgia's sake in memory of the fantastic times we shared. To appreciate it as a work of art, and a game design triumph.May be well past its prime, with a dead community and repetitive singleplayer... but pitch some Brink to me and I'll be down to play, any day.

												Oh my God. BRINK broke my heart.If I'm feeling unsure or too afraid to buy a game at launch, I still refer to it as "BRINK syndrome." Game looked amazing pre-release, with a fun parkour system and interesting class dynamics, slathered in delicious story. It wound up being a clunky mess with barely functional parkour and guns that felt like toys (seriously, the top-tier shotgun, which only heavies can use, takes two point blank shots to kill someone. The hell.)Don't buy this. Don't make eye contact. Don't give it any money. BRINK will just buy booze with it.

16, 2014
												Very solid team-based shooter. I played Enemy Territory competetively back in the day and always meant to pick up Brink, but got busy with other things and didn't want to get wrapped up in another multiplayer game at the time. Now that I've put some time into it I'm wondering what went wrong? It's a damn solid game... the few online games I managed to get into were extremely fun and there's a level of quality here that has really held up well over the last few years.In my opinion, Brink is one of those underestimated gems that could really benefit from the (yes, I know) free-to-play business model. A lot of people are probably hesitant to drop $20 on it, considering it rarely goes on sale- so they will never know how good it actually is. There's a ton of visual customization upgrades already built into the game, they should honestly just slap price tags on those and re-release Brink as F2P.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2013
												Brink is your standard establishment versus rebels (government v terrorists) FPS story arc. The game itself has a relatively weak story, told mostly by a 1-2 minute cutscene before each mission, first narrated by your commander giving objectives, then from the perspective of the soldiers. This game definitely didn't invest heavily in the campaign as it is basically a series of objective missions with AI, which means having a friend is definitely a plus as the missions become much more enjoyable when playing with friends. Even with this, the game takes less than 7 hours to clear 100% meaning low return on your funds. The gameplay offers combat most similar to Killzone 2, there is a class system and there are weapons useable across classes but they have their trade offs, and there is a unique feature of this game which is the parkour system (freerunning). The classes follow the Killzone style, with the soldier, sabateur, engineer, and medic which offer some class abilities which differentiate them from one another. Furthermore there is weapon customization like call of duty where you can modify your weapons with attachments, the good news is most of the attachments are easy to get, thus most people are on a level playing field. The leveling of characters unlocks more abilities and makes the character's more diverse, the classes are relatively balanced although personally the medic seems to be one of the stronger classes minus his inability to perform objectives (which is what all gamemodes are around). The parkour/freerunning mechanic is the main draw of this game, you can essentially climb any wall within reason, jump ledges, slide under obstacles or behind cover. It is a feature which worked well and gave the game a good "feel" to it, as your mobility was greatly increased. The graphics are relatively good despite the style leaving some things to be desired, some regions have low res textures (even on max), the character models look extremely similar even with the customization options (although the contrast of the slums and the ark is well done in level design/graphical appearance). The problem with this game at the time of writting this review is the online is effectively dead, either being too laggy or being nobody playing ever, which is kind of depressing because I did enjoy the game despite its flaws, and the game is obviously orientated towards multiplayer. As a result I cannot recommend this game unless you can purchase it for very cheap and are looking for a gaming experience which takes between 5-10hours for everything.

content:
er 3, 2013
												What to say about BRINK.Primarily -- do not buy this game: it is multiplayer focused and currently has no online community, rendering it a dead product.This is a game that was touted with a great amount of potential in its "free-running" parkour-like movement system, its stylised aesthetic full of realistic human models and the plurality of their costumes and faces.Ultimately, while these two strong selling points partially deliver, the game is let down by its pathetic Artificial Intelligence system and buggy mutliplayer implementation, which killed it before it got out of the gate. The class system based on experience provides questionable benefits requiring a huge investment of time to unlock, quite a long time after you will be bored of the game itself. The free-running aspect which has an interesting slant to it suffers in execution: it is too difficult to navigate, often vertically, while still combining gunplay and avoiding opponents in the first person perspective.Avoid.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
er 1, 2014
												Good mix of sp and mp game. Good audio-visuals. Nice (rather small/medium) maps. Great movement mechanics - very fluid. Various body types allow different weapons and different level of movement freedom (light - very fast and able to climb, medium - fast, but not that agile, thick - bullet sponge+turtle movement+no vertical advantage). Two factions offer different stories. Guns are ok and so are the perks. Classess are standard - engineer, assault, spy and medic. Customization of your character and weapons is pretty rich. Solo game allows bots, so you don't run all by yourself when people don't join. Game is objective based - there is no standard DM/TDM/CTF. I would say that it has potential, but something didn't click. It is still enjoyable even with bots - they tend to do well (not perfect but enough to win all maps and finish the story).  I still play it at times - a map or two. Fun thing.Performance on this is weird. It doesn't need powerful PC (I'd say weak on will do), but I faced sudden crashes on 2 of my machines (one under Win XP SP3 and Win 7 x64 Ultimate SP1 and laptop with Win 8.1 x64). Graphics is ok, nothing extreme in any direction. It has a touch of cartoon/cel shading. Sound is good (voice, guns, ambience). Controls are fine and the port seems solid (just those sudden crashes on different machines).

												Today's Review: BrinkPersonal Overview: At first i had doubts about this game, basically because by the time i got this game i was running on Windows 7 32bits, since the game requires at least a 64os system, i had to search for a patch to be able to play it, i was using the very same pc than that time but in that moment the game ran in minimun like crap (slow as 5 fps with fps drops and constant stuntering), 2 years later i've decided to install the game running under the same machine with Windows 7 64 and the experience was BEAUTIFUL, i'm talking about max resolution with high quality and even high quality process, and the game starts here:Brink is a first person shooter (FPS) set in a future where we live in the last human refugee "The ARK" a place is falling in decadence and there are 2 groups heavily armed and organized: one in favor to stay in the ARK in the middle of the ocean and fight for the place, and the other group wanting to leave and search for another place, game resambles pretty much the online part of call of duty black ops 2, history is set as multiplayer maps with an objective, there are some RPG factors as "abilities" (at first you think, i might trust ID to make an fps, they have a story with it, but bethesta? let me tell you, YES!)Overall Metascore: 87/100 "Exelent piece of work, get it!"

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												"The future of shooters..."yeah, that's what some big-time pre-reviewer said about the game months before it came out.Maybe "Brink" is the secret subconscious symbolic Illuminati slang-short for Boring(k).What can I say, for the past few months up until present half the New York City buses had the Brink ads on either side posted.The game has been given special care, very special care...by the advertisers. I also feel bad for people who pre-ordered this game.If one was to take one quick general look at the game, he or she wouldn't necessarily find anything wrong with it. But that's the thing about Brink. It has a catchy name and flashy gun fights, but underneath it all is either broken or overdone mechanics.Don't get me wrong, the weapon recoil is realistic and short burst from just about any gun will do the job. In general the gun-shooting feels right, but sometimes it does take more than a magazine clip to clip someone.I like the general mobility of the character you play but I was under the impression that there would be more wall bouncing, and more obstacles to easily climb on and climb through. So for the most part, you will end up doing the same thing: sprint, slow down, peek, crouch, shoot, step back and reload, repeat until you are dead or bleeding, respawn, repeat...Well, there are team objectives to complete, but most of these objectives are same or similar - we've seen it all before.I also realize that plenty of multiplayer games out there have the auto-healing, which I quite frankly despise. But this game takes it to a whole other level. Your health fully regenerates within 4-5 seconds, the only time you need a medic is when you are bleeding on the ground which is when a medic can run up and give you the adrenaline serum.There is also less than ten maps. And I KNOW what they are going to do next. In a couple of months or so, they will anounce a DLC with "ALL THREE NEW MAPS" for 10 bucks or so....There's no single-player to speak of. I mean it looks like there is one, but once you start playing for either the resistance or the security forces, all you end up with are short skits between skirmishes-NO STORY MODE. Each successful skirmish (map) is slightly harder than the previous one, but all it really is the multiplayer play against the AI - fulfilling the same redundant objectives over and over again.There are also mirror-edge kind of stunts that you can do, only i found the mechanics to be slightly awkward. If you bounce off the walls the right way, you also get points (same for kills) that you later use for customization. So the outcome of your stunts isn't always clear.I can't comment on the severity of the multiplayer bugs and the lag just yet. Maybe the PC servers are slightly better than their console counter-parts, or maybe I got lucky, but they are also much less numerous.The customization was meant to give the overt feeling of individualism, but in the end, it doesn't matter as much, at least to me. The ironic thing however is that after developing my character a little, I was more interested in customizing my weapons and dressing up my avatar as opposed to playing the actual game.Overall, the weapon customization is the one that matters, but that has all been done before in other games.The graphics aren't bad, but they aren't impressive either.I also found it interesting how the soldier class has infinite ammo. This was supposed to be the city on the b.r.i.n.k. of complete collapse, yet somehow you can have infinite ammo.Furthermore, the grenade explosions are laughable. You can also hear the sound of you running but if you look down, you will not see your legs. Also, since this is a port, the aim of your mouse will auto-aim for you as if you are a playing on a controller, cool huh?The so-called co-op in this game doesn't really apply. Because the single player is the same as the multiplayer. It's the same as playing co-op in Battlefield 2 BC, but at least that game has squads, and it is also better at doing everything, and stuff...All in all, there's no real incentive to help out your team mates by giving up your ammo and health serums. You can if you want to, but you don't have to. You can just continue blasting and hoping to get a kill. I am sorry for thinking back to Battlefield, but that game makes you want to help out your team mates and squad mates and rewards that splendid.One of my main gripes with the game is the way it was shown to be in previews and trailers. And that tells you a lot about the Art of Ads. I would also like to know what exactly is so revolutionary about this game.In general, I always thought that the future of shooters started with Battlefield Bad Company 2 and it will probably end with Battlefield 3.In the end, I think Bethesda should have focused more on making the next Fallout, only this time in NYC.P.S. The elongated, pickle-head faces are annoying

content:
er 25, 2013
												What was an interesting concept turned into a burning tire rolling down a hill. The game is well polished and has a interesting art style that isnt to bold but the fact that this "storytelling" game relys completely on multiplayer gameplay to flesh out the plot makes it crash and burn.I feel all games should be able to support themselves on some form of single player gameplay. If the player cannot enjoy the game by themselves then there isn't any point to it. Granted you can play with bots but after two "matches" the player feels confined in the adequately programmed AI. This game's multiplayer is dead as well since a majority of people who were interested in this game wised up and went on to do better things with their time.But if you have a bunch of friends and extra cash coupled with free time I can see this being a worth while thing. But that is the only circumstance this game is viable for.

content:
5, 2014
												I picked this game up for about 5 dollars on Amazon, because i was interested in it, but I though the price was too steep for a game that most people don't like. After playing for about an hour and 15 minutes (two campaign missions), it feels like a really solid shooter. The gunplay is great, it has proper recoil, and the guns don't slice through enemies like they're cheese. The story is ok from what I've played. Essentially, there's a floating city called "The Ark". After the seas started to flood, they went elsewhere, but some of the civilians want to leave and find other people. These are the rebellion. The Ark Security tries to stop them. It's really cliche, but interesting nonetheless. All in all, it's a really solid game, and almost all of the bugs that inhibitted gameplay have been fixed at this point.

content:
, 2016
												Em primeiro lugar uma decepção sem dúvida alguma.BRINK é um jogo de tiro em primeira pessoa desenvolvido pela Splash Damage e publicado pela Bethesda Softworks para Windows, PlayStation 3 e Xbox 360 Lançado em 2011.Brink tem lugar na Arca, uma cidade feita pelo homem flutuante que está à beira de uma guerra civil.Ela deveria abrigar 5.000 pessoas, no entanto está abrigando aproximadamente 50.000. Desta forma, esta situação se torna insustentável e os residentes começam a ficar rapidamente insatisfeitos com a falta de comida, roupas e água potável, assim nasce  "Resistance", que luta pela adequado fornecimento desses suprimentos. Com as tensões entre os dois grupos em crescimento, forças de segurança e resistência são trancados em uma batalha aquecida para o controle da Arca.Após a negação deste fornecimento pelos líderes da Arca, a Resistance se prepara para tentar tomar o poder e distribuir água e comida gratuitamente, uma vez que defendem a idéia de que a Arca tem recursos renováveis suficientes para tal. Com as tensões entre os dois grupos em crescimento, forças de Security e Resistance são trancados em uma batalha aquecida para o controle da Arca.É possível jogar com ambas as facções, Security ou Resistance.Single-player, co-op e jogabilidade multiplayer até 16 jogadore uma experiência perfeita, também permitindo-lhe desenvolver o seu personagem. BRINK focado em movimentos de Parkour aonde precisamente não tem nada de especial, depois não existe prazer ao jogar simplesmente não da vontade de continuar o que é muito negativo.Tinha tudo para ser um excelente jogo mas falhou.Já tentei jogar este jogo 3 vezes 3 oportunidades para mim é impossivel não consigo.Which side will you choose?Humiliation ★☆☆☆☆

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2015
												The poster-boy for failure to launch. The trailers and previews were dotted with lies, talking about a "seamless experience" and how you would want to fight with your faction to "control" parts of the ARK. Consistently, they implied it would be an MMOFPS-style game, where you'd move between zones, then be pulled into multiplayer encounters.What we got was a bog-standard, class-based, objective-focused FPS with a half-baked parkour system, decent character customization, janky controls and extremely spotty hit detection/lag compensation. Regularly you will die without knowing why, or pound a clip into an opponent only to be killed by a single shot in reprisal.As others have said, this game is garbage. Ignoring the fact that the servers are likely dead as hell by now, it should be a stern reminder (and is to me,) to never preorder without all the facts. I wish that the store rating system had existed back when Brink came out--I could've helped save a lot of people 60$.I still wear the TF2 hat they gave me for preordering as a reminder to be vigiliant.As a reminder... of my shame.

												i'm started playing single player 3 nights ago 8/28/2014, installed from DVD and activated and updated through steam. i get under 20FPS and overclocking my FX8350 to 4.4 had no effect, so it is not a CPU bottleneck, also my HD7870 is @30-40%i struggled through the first few missions with the 17-19fps on the rebel side until i noticed the broken AI. i'm on a defend mission for the first 5 and a half minutes of defending i kill about 15 enemies, with most of the fighting being done in a different area by the AI controlled players.  then the last 30 seconds of the defense hits, then ALL OF THE ENEMY AI converge on my point, i manage to kill 1-2, then the 17-19fps drops even lower to a 10-15fps making it to were the AI are able to kill me and i feel like i am moving in slow motion, which is sickning.  so they capture point 1, some doors open then i have to defend a safe. same story, no enemies close to the objective for the time of the mission, until the last 30 seconds, then all of them converge on the point, take it in to overtime and also dropping the frame rate back down to 10-15fps, if it wasn't for me having a little better of a position they would of won.

												Oo, This Game... For any of you that Haven't seen Angry Joe's review of this Game, let me Summarize:Brink is an unfinished, buggy as hell, frustrating mess of a game that has a lot of great ideas, but little to no Execution. content:
er 28, 2015
												The poster-boy for failure to launch. The trailers and previews were dotted with lies, talking about a "seamless experience" and how you would want to fight with your faction to "control" parts of the ARK. Consistently, they implied it would be an MMOFPS-style game, where you'd move between zones, then be pulled into multiplayer encounters.What we got was a bog-standard, class-based, objective-focused FPS with a half-baked parkour system, decent character customization, janky controls and extremely spotty hit detection/lag compensation. Regularly you will die without knowing why, or pound a clip into an opponent only to be killed by a single shot in reprisal.As others have said, this game is garbage. Ignoring the fact that the servers are likely dead as hell by now, it should be a stern reminder (and is to me,) to never preorder without all the facts. I wish that the store rating system had existed back when Brink came out--I could've helped save a lot of people 60$.I still wear the TF2 hat they gave me for preordering as a reminder to be vigiliant.As a reminder... of my shame.

er 22, 2011
												Brink? More like Uninstalled: The Video GameUgh I was really hesitant to buy this knowing full well what I was getting into and folded to peer pressure by people who quite honestly were ignorant of the game's development history. I don't claim to be an expert on it, but I knew I played enough QUAKE WARS to know that Brink was a game to wait on reviews for before purchasing.I viewed Quake Wars as a preview to Brink's philosophy. Quake Wars required intense pub cooperation that was above and beyond most players' expectations of simple and straightforward team deathmatch.Brink's primarily failing was pretty simple to me. It didn't present a preview of each map to the player, leading everybody who played it to get lost, or behave in a way that was disadvantageous to them because of designed ignoranceThe game's pacing is just plain slow and unrewarding. Even the competitive scene panned this game, The GIANTBOMB.COM CLICK QUICK LOOK http://www.giantbomb.com/brink/61-26694

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
y 19
												0/10 completely worthless because of one of the dumbest things I've ever seen, it locks your fps to 30 in offline solo play, which is bad since mp has been dead from day 1, and because its overall quality is severely lacking and is often completely deprived of basic necessary qualities.I've always wanted to see if this was decent because it looked alright and I read you could set up your own dedicated private server to play solo to avoid the incredibly stupid 30 fps single player cap. I got it for $3 on humblebundle and did all that. Turns out you can't progress the campaign missions that way, it's just private online solo play. Offline solo locks the game at 30fps, online solo/co-op lets you hit 60fps. One of the dumbest things I've ever seen. Anyway, I was lucky and when I selected campaign online co-op mode there was amazingly a couple servers and one had a 50 ping so I could actually play the campaign missions at 60fps. I was the only person on it with 15 other bots of course. But how long would that server be up and why was it in the first place? Who knows who ♥♥♥♥ing cares, time to give the game a fair chance.It turned out to be the worst team shooter I have ever played, like a really crappy rip-off of TF2. It is junky, clunky, and janky, with the graphics and sounds being its only worthwhile points. The only game mode I saw was either defend a point or attack a point. The side objectives are mostly pointless and are just worthless distractions from the real goal. Some are useful, like blowing up a wall to make a shorter point to the objective, but the enemy can easily swarm it, kill you and all the bots there, and patch it up, or just close it back up when nobody is around which is very easily done. So really the gameplay is extremely basic.Teammate AI can be decent but are mostly just a bunch of dumber than hell bots. Enemy AI is worse and are very poorly balanced. They either stand there while you kill them, fire back a little, or are one-shot kill masters. That was the biggest problem I came across and it is bad. Quite often when you suddenly come up on a enemy they will one-shot headshot kill you in a millisecond before you can react. It is extremely annoying. The other huge problem that is constantly aggravating is some of the most annoying knockback I have ever seen. It is caused by enemies melee'ing you when in close or by grenade blast radius. Your entire view gets knocked back and lowered to simulate a knockback/knockdown combination effect. It is violent and jarring and massively irritating. It's like getting the most annoying video game b-tch slap in gaming history and it happens a lot. As far as the missions go, some are easily fail-able with no proper indication as to why. I failed mission 5 3 times in a row when I thought we were doing well, defending a point that it told me to. That was the point when combined with the overall bad quality of the entire game, made me uninstall this and try to forget I ever wasted my time on this total mess.The game is just overall a badly executed poor man's version of much more competent team shooters like TF2 and even another dead game, Battleborn. In fact this game makes me want to actually reinstall Battleborn just to play the new mission and two new characters they put out since I quit.

content:
20, 2013
												Most dissapointing game of 2011? Yeah. All the hype created over those trailers- the beautiful concept and possibility.I blame the developers for their decision to stray from the intended path and into the "cartoonish" and unrealistic mess the game turned out to be. Personally, I'm not a fan of playing the same storyline twice with only minimal changes(Plant the bomb this time, stop them from planting the bomb next time)- Not only does the campaign have you do both storylines, no time has passed in the game either way- playing as the Security stopping the Rebels from planting the bomb you planted during your Rebel playthrough, for example. The only thing about this game more broken than the story is the combat, nobody dies until you have killed them twice.  First you have to knock them down, say with a headshot of a couple slugs to the chest, you then have to do the same once more to kill them.Just get Blacklight: Retribution, much better, free, not BRINK.

												The game was disappointing enough as a full-price retail release that required Steamworks. It delivers on none of the hype, and a lack of care permeates every aspect of its design, from the imbalanced maps and weapons to the completely uninspired unlock system and lack of features or content. To this day, the game feels unfinished and barely received support after launch. A stain on the name of the studio who brought you the Enemy Territory series, not even Bethesda wants anything to do with it, as they've apparently shut down the master server and now you can only connect directly to servers by specifying IP addresses. A true example of squandered potential, it's not worth your money or your time.

content:
er 29, 2013
												Brink is a perfect example of a brillinat idea that is executed in a soso manner. Enemy territory players will feel pretty much at home with this, it tries something fresh in terms of every match having a story, a reason behind it, with outcomes based on the winning team. Art style is pretty nice, customization is very fun to use (only issue is you can't custom color your items, just pre-sets.) Sadly I am not sure if many people still play this game, as it had mixed to poor critical review due to bad console versions, but you would have to look into that if you are interested. The game is not for everyone, but if it is for you, someone who loves team based games with a twist, you'll adore this game and look past the flaws. If you are looking for just pure shooter, avoid it.

content:
r 9, 2014
												Tl;dr: A fun FPS that brings something new into the market. If you're into Character Customization, be warned that there aren't female characters.Brink is a fun game overall. Gameplay is nice, teams are balanced, and nobody goes home a loser. The fighting is relatively simple. Aim, shoot, kill. But then you factor in ammo resupplies, damage buffs, and armor enhancement, and it complicates the equation. Complicate meaning "funnifies" in this usage. Plus, the movement is unique. Holding sprint activates a kind of "dynamic parkour" feature that allows you to find new paths and move around more fluidly. This also allows for some characters to vault walls taller than them. Class perks and abilities are cool, being able to give someone a damage buff or resupply of ammo. There is also a cool perk system, which as you level up allows for more abilities and tricks to be available to the character. Instead of set perks, they are bought by level coins, a nice feature in my opinion.The story is engaging, albeit short. Depending on which side you play, you get both sides of the story. You can replay any mission as either side and learn their views and reason for fighting. Alongside the main campaign (which can be played solo or multiplayer), there is freeplay and challenges. Freeplay is exactly what it sounds like. Challenges are different tasks that test your ability to use the ingame skillset. The only qualm I have is with 'Parkour This'; I love the parkour aspect of the fighting, but in no way did I ask for you to require me to master it to unlock silencers.I love the character customization. Very simple, clean, and creative. Two things: No girls, and no custom facial/bodily features. I find the lack of girls sad (if you emphasize character customization, you dang better have both genders!) but not game ruining. Yeah, it'd be nice to seduce my enemies into not shooting me, but it's okay to have only guys. The only thing that really grinds my gears is that you are locked to a specific set of facial setups. No big pouty lips and anime eyes here, just a couple dozen near identical faces. On the bright side, each clothing piece comes in an assortment of colors (which often change the patterns of the clothes as well). The face paint and tattoos partially fulfill me in the way of face modification. Overall it's nice, but still makes the character customization just feel like chara custo.One aspect this game displays nicely in gun modification. You can attach multiple enhancements to your gun. That's it. You get a few sights, a couple muzzle brakes (purely cosmetic, still fun), and if you try hard enough, silencers and speed holsters/slings. No camos, nor extreme performance enhancements (which adds to the argument of team balance).Overall I give it an 8.5/10, really fun to play, but has a couple bugs and missing features that kind of harm the gameplay. If you have the money, it's worth it.8.5/10, would knockdown again.(Btw, the reason I complain about Brink not having girls while CoD and Battlefield don't is that advertising character customization implies having women; and I don't think that CoD or Battlefield said that there was a totall of 100+ quadrillion total combinations.)

content:
r 11, 2014
												This game is beyond the most strategic and action-packed arena game as of late. Indeed the characters are curiously modeled, but it's just Brink's unique graphics. No other arena game- save perhaps Halo Reach, has such a multitude of combinations to create a truly unique character. I suppose there may not be anymore dedicated servers, I've never noticed a different between them and private hosted servers, which Brink has.If you haven't bought the game; buy it. And if you own it, join the Brink universe again, get it back on it's feet.Call of Duty has an impressive arsenal, sure, but there's absolutely no strategy involved, and I'm not certain as I've given up on that franchise, but as far as I'm concerned doesn't have character customizations, as with Brink, your character evolves as you progress. And the combat, with some games it's too complex, or the game itself pratically fights for you, but with Brink you have inumerable ways to approach a firefight, with inumerable guns, and as a character with no equal.

												This game is actually no worse than Battlefield 4 and other similar titles like Call of Duty. The problem is Battlefield and Call of Duty are mediocre games, and they use expensive marketing, DLC packages, yearly releases, and massive funding to stay in business. content:
r 15, 2014
												For all that hipsters and cynics love to mock it, we owe a lot to Brink. It was Brink that set the benchmark for how shooters looked and played in the HD era. It was Brink that redefined the FPS as all-action blockbuster, while transforming multiplayer.The premise is interesting, albeit faintly ridiculous. In the near future a new power – The Federation – rises in South America and its influence begins to spread across the world.  Federation forces attack a US orbital weapon and turn its weapons of mass destruction against the US, blasting half of the states back into the stone age and putting an end to North American dominance of the region.Brink's one shining aspect is SMART (Smooth Movement Across Random Terrain). Using SMART, holding a single button lets you navigate up walls, over obstacles, and through the game world. Depending on your body size, you can do more or less with movement, but overall this finesse is fantastic. Nothing in Brink feels quite as good as sliding under gunfire into someone, taking them out with a shotgun.Brink is by far the worst ♥♥♥♥ing game my friends have ever played! 7/10 A Masterpiece.

content:
er 7, 2011
												Weird. That's the word that fits BRINK the most imo. The game does a terrible job at explaining itself and you can easily get confused by the cartoony graphics, that make you think that this must be an over the top TF2 style game that allows you to do silly stuff for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles right? WRONG. If you want a tight team based game then keep your eye on this title as you'll be hard pressed to find another game that requires more teamwork than this. This game is nigh-impossible to solo/lone-wolf. The only game mode available is objective based. Some objectives can alter the map layout. Combat is medium to close quarters oriented. All weapons/unlocks become available when you finish the tutorial. Only class specific abilities are xp based. 4 classes. Best avatar editor in a FPS game yet. Game encourages you to make different characters tied to different classes. Different body types allow different levels of parkour traversal through the maps. Team players need only apply.
